_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Southwest Cheese Company uses anhydrous ammonia to cool spaces for cheese storage and production.  Ammonia is the only hazardous chemical used at this facility that is subject to the federal Accidental Release Prevention (RMP) Program requirements.

This facility recognizes the hazards associated with the use of highly hazardous chemicals.  As a reflection of our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations, we submit this plan to address the hazards inherent with the use of ammonia.  Our program addresses safety precautions regarding the handling and operation of this covered system as well as proper training for those who operate and maintain the system.  The company training policy requires that all employees will be properly trained for a job position before assignment to that job.

Our accidental release prevention program is clearly defined by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program for this facility.  This prevention program follows industry-recommended standards for preventing unnecessary human exposures and reducing the threat to the health of our employees as well as to members of the community and the surrounding area.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle these chemicals, the safety devices inherent in the design of this facility and its processes, and the training that we provide our personnel.  This Plan is updated as required by law.

Our Emergency Action Plan (EAP) details the response this facility will take as a result of an uncontrolled release of ammonia.  The Plan includes procedures for notification of the local emergency responders.  This EAP also includes a specific protocol for responding to an ammonia release and assigns an Emergency Coordinator to implement the response.  This Plan is current and updated as required by law and conforms to the requirements for an Emergency Action Plan as per 29 CFR 1910.38.

This facilit

y has also coordinated with the local emergency responders and will maintain close contact to ensure that the responders are familiar with the system and with the general safety and accidental release program at our plant.

It is the policy of this facility to devote the time, energy, and capital toward maintaining prevention and response programs appropriate to the inherent dangers with the use of hazardous chemicals.

 
THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Stationary Source

The SouthWest Cheese Company facility is a joint venture between Glanbia Foods, Select Milk Producers (SMP) and Dairy Farmers of America (DFA).  Glanbia is responsible for running the plant production, warehousing, and distribution, while SMP and DFA will guarantee the milk requirements of the plant, which will be approximately 6.6 million pounds milk per day.  The 300,000 square foot facility lies on a 3,000-acre site southwest of the town of Clovis, New Mexico.

Considered to be North America¿s largest cheddar cheese production plant, the facility will produce blocks of cheese weighing as much as 640 pounds.  It is expected that annual production will reach 250 million pounds of cheese and 16.5 million pounds of whey proteins using 2.3 billion pounds of milk.  The new facility will employ 205 workers when it reaches full production.

Project design was provided by Power Engineers of Hailey, Idaho and E.A. Bonelli & Associates of Oakland, California.  Dahlgren Group of Seattle, Washington and the Carlisle Group from Minnesota are constructing the plant.  Applied Process Cooling Corporation (APCCO) of Modesto, California is providing the design and installation of the ammonia refrigeration system.

The SouthWest Cheese Company plant is located at 1141 Curry Road 4 about six miles south of Clovis and Highways 60/84 and about two miles west of Highway 70.  The Clovis site was chosen for its proximity to a large, well-developed dairy producing region.  The plant is surround

ed by approximately 100 acres of grassland and wheat and there are two large dairies about 2 miles away.

Clovis lies nine miles west of the Texas border town of Texico in Curry County in east-central New Mexico.  There are approximately 35,000 people living in Clovis, which was incorporated in 1909.  Prevailing winds are from the south and southeast.

Regulated Substance Handled

The SouthWest Cheese Company facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a heat transfer fluid in the plant refrigeration system.  The system is a single-stage mechanical refrigeration system that utilizes direct liquid feed to glycol heat exchangers, which provide chilled glycol to the evaporator coils.  Cooling is required for production and storage of the product.

The heat of compression in the high-pressure compressor discharge is removed in the evaporative condensers.  The condenser drains high-pressure liquid to the thermosiphon vessel for screw compressor cooling, which in turn, transfers high-pressure liquid to the high-pressure receiver (HPR).  Liquid from the HPR is transferred to the recirculator package (RP01) as needed for heat exchange and cooling in the evaporators via the glycol system.

PRIMARY SYSTEM COMPONENTS

(4)   Screw Compressor Packages
(3)   Evaporative Condensers
(1)   Thermosiphon Receiver
(1)   High-Pressure Receiver
(1)   Liquid Transfer Unit
(3)   Plate and Frame Heat Exchangers
(1)   Recirculator with ammonia pumps 
(1)   Oil Pot
(3)   Glycol Pumps and Glycol Expansion Tank
(13) Evaporator Coil Units

Additional system components include:

Interconnecting piping; and
Control valves

Safety systems include:

	   Pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels;
	   Compressor safety cutouts and control panels to shut down the compressor operation if safe operating conditions are exceeded;
	   Liquid level float switches;
	   High level vessel alarms;
	   Ventilation system for continuous and emergency ventilation;
	   Emergency Control Station with emergency ventil

artup safety review, hot work permitting, management of change, mechanical integrity, incident investigation, compliance audits, and emergency response.

Those who operate, maintain, or supervise the system will be trained to understand the principles of ammonia refrigeration and ammonia properties, an understanding of the process equipment and proper operating and maintenance procedures, recognition of abnormal conditions and the steps to correct deviations, and emergency shutdown procedures as appropriate to the level of involvement each employee will have with the process.  Contractors that perform maintenance or that design changes to the system will be qualified by the facility based upon their experience and safety record before being selected to provide such services.

The general safety program includes hazardous communication, forklift operation, first aid, emergency response, confined space entry procedures, lockout / tagout procedures, and additional programs as necessary to maintain a safe operation.

THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

This process is a new system process and, therefore, has no operational history.
 
THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Employees are trained to understand the requirements of the Emergency Action Plan.  The Emergency Action Plan includes release notification for emergency responders and the procedures for evacuation.  The Emergency Coordinator implements the response in coordination with the local emergency responders (i.e. the fire department).  It is the policy and practice to conduct evacuation drills at least twice per year.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

An initial Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed as required for the ammonia refrigeration system.  The PHA team developed a list of recommendations to improve safety by reducing potential hazards of the process.  All recommendations were either implemented immediately or deemed unnecessary after careful review since no improvements to safety would result.

No add

itional changes to improve safety are currently planned.  Ongoing programs for training, mechanical integrity, management of change, incident investigation, and compliance audits are in place to ensure that future concerns for improved safety are addressed and implemented as required in a timely manner.
